awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Blockchain-Enabled Patient Centric Consent To Improve Access To Care
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a software system that will allow patients’ efficient accessibility to medical second opinions using distributed ledger technology. The proposed solution is fundamentally different than existing solutions. Recent studies identified barriers to the market including long waiting times and unclear costs. The current second opinion solutions do not address the interoperability and information silo problem, and they keep the burden of collecting information on patients. Patients provide records to the best of their ability, but unfortunately many times the information they provide is insufficient, and not specific to their visit, which occasionally requires repeat imaging/testing/studies. The proposed solution saves physicians time and addresses current barriers of non-technical patients as it simplifies, organizes, and efficiently presents this information to a physician for a clear picture of the patient's condition. Current medical second opinion market size is estimated to be $7.1 Billion by 2025.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a distributed ledger technology that solves the challenge faced by patients to have their complete medical charts available for dissemination. Currently, the information resides is with different modalities and transparency requirements and is scattered among various physicians and institutions. The proposed technology uses the distributed ledger built-in infrastructure to support seamless patient control, notification, and even compensation, when permitted by law, every time their data is accessed and used. Having the data attached with a distributed ledger infrastructure enables an automated tracing mechanism that may support a transparent use of data any time. The technology helps minimize the patients waiting time by ensuring the accessibility of the collected patient records to physicians. In addition, it helps the patient with the cost estimation of the second opinion by preventing unnecessary tests already done.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our project goal is to enhance patient-centric healthcare. The intellectual merit of our endeavor lies in our approach to leverage existing Health Information Exchange (HIE) platforms, which streamlines the retrieval of relative clinical data. This data, once harnessed, is efficiently provided to a patient's chosen physician for a timely review and virtual consultation. Addressing the challenge of fragmented patient data due to existing information silos, our approach emphasis on patient needs. Central to our innovation is the application of distributed ledger infrastructure (Blockchain). This not only guarantees automatic patient control but also ensures transparency by providing notifications and potential compensation when their data is accessed, compliant with legal guidelines.

The broader impact of our work include our extensive stakeholder engagement, aimed at refining our value proposition. This was further expanded upon by our participation in tradeshows and further stakeholder interactions. The feedback from our SBIR proposal was invaluable, offering insights that will shape our future endeavors and ensure their alignment with broader healthcare needs.

An exciting milestone was the interest expressed by an industry partner . Their willingness to collaborate accentuates the potential of our approach and its broader societal impacts. Together, we aim to develop a proof of concept to be applied at the state level in New Jersey, ensuring that our solutions have real-world applicability and broader societal relevance. This collaboration is pivotal as it sets the stage for a joint submission for a PFI to develop a prototype, leveraging the proof of concept capabilities to cater to wider patient needs.

Knowledge dissemination and building capacity is manifested in our involvement with the University of Scranton. We revamped a graduate health informatics course, ensuring that it reflects the latest industry trends.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Ahmed A Gomaa
